Follow the adventures of Dominique Schummer, a dynamic company director, as he grapples with the issue of personal data protection and moves step by step towards compliance with the GDPR.
Focus on data protection!
Dominique
Jeanine
Charlotte Kieffer
Judith
Bruno

Hello Jeanine!

How was your holiday in Portugal?

In any case, you're looking great!

Hi Dominique!

Yes, it was amazing!

We stayed with my husband's parents and came back with a tan!

I'm sorry to have to get you back into the swing of things straight away, but I've just received an email from a client discussing to me about the GDPR and access rights...

I don't understand it myself, but maybe you've already heard of it?

The GDPR? Of course I'm familiar with it!

It's a European legal text about personal data protection and  it imposes certain obligations on companies and organisations that hold such data.

But what does this have to do with me?

We're a small company just trying to grow.

So what does this mean in practical terms?

As far as I know, all companies based in Luxembourg that manage personal data, as well as public authorities, are affected, so we're affected too!

The simplest thing is for you to call me this evening and we can talk about it.
Perfect! Thank you! Talk to you tonight!
Email from the customer

Dear Sir,

In accordance with Article 15 of the GDPR, I would like to exercise my right to access.

I would be grateful if you could send me a copy of my personal data within the statutory period of one month.

Yours sincerely

GDPR, protection of personal data, all that is fine and good, but what does a small company like mine have to do with it?

As far as I'm concerned, it's more about the web giants collecting personal data willy-nilly!

But Jeanine seems to think otherwise.

What if I did a bit of research on the web?
Result found on the Website of the European Commission

"Yes, the application of the Data Protection Regulation does not depend on the size of your business/organisation but on the nature of your activities."

More generally, the GDPR "regulates the processing by a person, business or organisation of personal data relating to individuals within the EU", including public administrations and associations."
Time to find out more
Hello?

Good Evening Jeanine !

Sorry to contact you outside of business hours ...

Hi Dominique!

No bother, don't worry it's fine!

As your accountant I'm always glad to help!
So could you tell me what the GDPR is?

It is a European law designed to protect the personal data of individuals like you and me.

To do this, it imposes certain obligations on companies and organisations that collect and process this data.
What kind of obligations are these?

There are quite a few of them, but I could mention IT security obligations, for example.

Above all, however, they serve to inform people when you are processing their data and to respond to their requests when they assert a right... for example the right of access that your customer mentions in her email!
So what do I have to do now exactly?
Well, to reply correctly to this email, you're going to have to list all the data your company holds on your costumer and send it to them!
As you seem to know all about it, couldn't you help me with this process?

Well Dominique, I would like to help you, but our accountancy is already working with an external DPO, a data protection officer.

If you are interested I could give you his contact details.
I'll think about it….

In the meantime, you'll find all the relevant information on the website of the competent Luxembourgish authority, the CNPD, The National Commission for Data Protection.

I'll text you their web address.

Judith, our data base contains personal data: names, first names, addresses, emails, etc....

Could you please catalog them?

Please focus on individuals, forget about companies and organizations.

The aim is to catalog all personal data and to identify how and by whom the data is used.

Focus first on our costumer data. We'll tackle the employee and supplier data at a later date...
No problem Dominique, but how can you tell if something is a personal data or not?
Apparently you can find all the relevant information on the website of the national authority, cnpd.lu
So, how is it going?

According to the CNPD, personal data is "any information that relates to an identified or identifiable living individual."
By the way, I think that their website is great!
Understandable, since in a country like Luxembourg where everybody knows everybody, data protection is essential!

The website also mentions photos and CCTV surveillance.
So I will have to include the photo and video files?

If they mention them, they will have to be included.
In regards to Mrs. Kieffer's e-mail, could you please catalog all the information we have on her?
This is a very important step in order to reply to her!
On my part, I will retrace the history of all our e-mail campagnes with our sales person.
We will have to record in a clear and precis document all the used personal data and the reasons why that data was used.
Thank you for your help!
Hello Bruno, how are you doing?

Hello, Dominique: A part from the daily traffic jams on the A31, everything is fine.
How are you?

I'm great, thank you.
Listen, I need your help to retrace the usage of our costumer's data.
Do you have a few minutes?
Sure!Tell me how can I help!

We have a data base containing our costumer's personal data.
I will need to know how that data is used, what for and by whom!

The costumer data that I use daily is mainly on our CRM.
But for our last emailng campagn I used Judith's Access data base.
And what do we do with that data?

Concerning the B2C, we just tested a marketing email campagne but we haven't launched our newsletter yet.
As soon as our website is online, we will be able to better target our costumers.

Besides, the personal data that I have on our CRM are those of our biggest B2B costumers.
That data, how did we collect it?

By two means: Firstly there is Judith's Access data base that is used for billing.That data base contains the data of individuals who ordered something from us at least once.
Concerning the CRM, I collected that data while networking or attending events or expositions.
I haven't used LinkedIN yet and we haven't bought a third party data base.
Who can access the CRM?
Only you and me
And the Access data base for emailing?
I personally automated the emailing from Excel and I don't use any other spedific application.

Wow, you already have the right GDPR reflexes?
That's really good.
Can you please coordinate with Judith, who is cataloging the data?
Consider it done!

Good morning Judith!
Where are we with regards to the GDPR?

Hi Dominique !

A lot of progress has been made concerning the mapping of the data.

I have finished the mapping of the data-processing activities.
Great!Has Bruno gotten back to you?

Yes, we have mapped everything: the costumer data, but also the data of the employees and the suppliers processed by our accountant.
We are really greatful to Jeanne, who has done an amazing job!
So what's our next step now?
I have created an initial email based on the information I found on the CNPD's website. I will be gradually add more relevant information…
Judith, I don't know about you, but regarding the customer's right of access, I wonder if it wouldn't be simpler to simply delete all of her personal data?

I'm sorry, Dominique, but you can't bury your head in the sand!

 In her email, Ms Kieffer asks for a clear answer.

What's more, I'm afraid this is in breach of the GDPR...

It's imperative that we react and reply to her!

Dominique, we've hit a brick wall!

Given that Kieffer is a very common name in the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, we have two Charlotte Kieffers in our database, with two different addresses, and one of them has no email address.
Contact our IT support, there has to be a solution.
Yes, but in absolute terms, how can you be sure that the person using an email address is the right person?
Listen, you'll probably find the answer on the CNPD's website!

As far as Charlotte Kieffer is concerned, there's another point to bear in mind.

She is the contact person for a contract with one of our biggest customers.
So we are faced with another problem: how do we deal with a request for access to a document covered by a confidentiality clause?
What's more, the preliminary contract that mentions it also refers to other people... Anything else?
Yes, in addition to the content to be sent in response to the request, you need to define who is sending the email!
As manager, I suppose I'm the one who has to do it!
Yes, but since this our first response of this kind, we could take the opportunity to create an rgpd@ email address!
Good idea. Please look into that with our IT support!

Dominique, I've just remembered that we also have a paper archive at the back of the warehouse under the footbridge and others externally at CompactLux.

Most of these documents have not yet been digitised and the only references to them are in Excel files.

If we have to go through all the paper files to check the relationship with our customer, we'll be here for months!

As for the files at CompactLux, we'll have to wait a week before we can retrieve the boxes.

I've found out that the deadline for a response is 1 month after receipt of the request. Beyond that, we can extend the period under certain conditions, otherwise we risk a penalty.

How much time do we have left?

We will have to hurry up!
We've got barely a week left!

Fortunately, you can extend the deadline by 2 months, provided you inform the person in question.

Since I'm the one who has to process the application, I'll do it myself!

This story is likely to cost me a lot of money with all the people I've had to mobilise: my IT support, my archiving company, not to mention the working time of my administrative assistant and my sales person ...

I'm wondering whether I might be able to claim compensation ...

Well, Dominique, as soon as I get the latest invoices from the suppliers, I'll be able to deduct the VAT and the VAT returns will be ready... You know that the Tax Administration doesn't mess around with these things!
Don't worry, I'll get back to you as soon as I can!

Perfect !
So, how is it going with your costumer and her request to acces?
Luckily Judith sent the response, with a copy of the costumer's data,  last Thursday at the 11th hour.

Congratulations! Another job well done!
You must be relieved?
Well, not really…Mrs Kieffer replied the next day with an erasure request !

Well it's her right!
But what exactly did she want?
In particular, she was concerned about the lack of information on the data processing …

Well, soon you'll be able to inform all interested parties about it on your new website, telling them who processes their personal data, why and how!

We call this the principle of transparency!

As for the right to erasure, I know that there are conditions to be met when exercising this right, but I can't remember exactly what they are.

The best thing would be for you to ask the CNPD to find out.
Is there a fee?

No, not at all !
Most of all, they will reply quickly and comprehensively.
Don't forget that we are in Luxembourg, a country of short travels and paths.
By the way, you're certain that you don't want to hire a DPO ?
I have to admit I'm seriously considering it….
Back at the office with Judith
OK, Dominique, I'm on the form!

Perfect !

The easiest way is to repeat what is in the customer's e-mail: right to be forgotten, obsolete data... and then?
Purposes of processing…
Purposes and don't forget about the absence of consent

Mrs Kieffer is asking for all of her data to be erased.
Would that be possible?

It depends.
Actually the right to erasure is not absolute.
At least that's what Jeanine told me?
Ok, can I send it?
Yes, click on confirm, we'll see what the CNPD's reply will be….

Hello, Judith !

In fact I already have the CNPD's reply !

Already !? The're quick, those guys !

That took less than a week….

I've transferred it to you. Would you be willing to draw up an action plan on this basis?

In a nutshell: we need to define the purposes for which the data was collected, the cases in which customer consent is required, the legal basis, the limits on data retention and compliance with the principle of accountability.
So, first of all, we need to check whether the processing complies with the purposes for which Mrs Kieffer's data was collected?
That's exactly right! As a reminder, the purposes in Mrs Kieffer's case were, on the one hand, to draw up an invoice and, on the other, to create a loyalty card.
On the form she signed when applying for her loyalty card, a simple paragraph stated that by doing so she was consenting to receiving offers from us…
As a result, she had given her consent to our advertising campaigns being sent to her!

It's not that simple !
From what I understand, certain conditions have to be met for a consent to be considered valid.
Notably, being able to tick a box to clearly and actively approve your wishes.
This was not the case with the the form we had her sign…
So, Mrs Kieffer never consented to receiving our promotional offers?

That's the problem !
And according to the CNPD, even if the consent was valid, which I higly doubt, she could revoke it at any moment....
Reassure me: even if the consent we have collected is not valid, that doesn't  mean we have to stop our email campaigns?

No, consent does of course allow us to process data for canvassing purposes, but it is not the only legal basis.

If I remember correctly, in addition to consent, there is also the legitimate interest, the public interest mission, the contract, the legal obligation and the safeguarding of vital interests.

So there are several ways of staying within the law...
What would I do without you…
You'd do what I did: check the CNPD website!
Hello, Bruno, do you have a moment ?

Sure, I was about to go pick up my meal vouchers, but that can wait.

Tell me…

I've heard  that you can canvass a person who is already a customer without asking for their consent again if it concerns products or services similar to those they've already purchased, provided you give them the option of objecting by withdrawing their consent.

Is this true?

Yes !

In this case, the legitimate interest of the company takes precedence, but the customer must be informed when the data is collected that his or her e-mail address will be used for canvassing purposes.

The customer in question hasn't bought anything from us for over 5 years and we haven't contacted her since.

And now she's complaining that she's been contacted again today!

I have to admit that I can understand that.
Can we really still consider her a costumer after all this time?

One day, we sold her a product, so personally, I still consider her to be our customer!

But maybe I'm wrong…

Sorry to disappoint you, but according to the CNPD, we cannot keep personal data for longer than is necessary to achieve the purposes for which it is collected and processed.

After that, the data must be deleted or made anonymous.

So the 5 years during which Mrs Kieffer did not buy anything from us is too long to still consider her a customer!
So what should we  do ?

Now, when we want to send her a commercial email, we will have to apply the rules related to the prospecting of non - customers, i.e. to obtain their prior consent and provide them with all the information required by the GDPR.
Understood ! So we shouldn't have approached our former customer in this way, given that her e-mail address should already have been deleted from our customer database?
Exactly ! Come to think, I may have the solution to satisfy both sides: the implementation of a tool to periodically re-ask for costumers' consent!

So, Dominique, Mrs Kieffer is back at it again!

In the new e-mail you sent me, she complains that we've collected too much information about her.

Not least thanks to her loyalty card…
That's true, and yet we didn't ask her for any intrusive data!

Yes, but you're forgetting the famous principle of minimisation!

According to this principle, we only have the right to process the data that is necessary for the intended purpose.

For the loyalty programme, you should therefore limit the collection of personal data to essential information, such as name, address, telephone number and e-mail address.
So, what is wong ?
The problem is that the entire date of birth has been collected, which is excessive in relation to this principle.
And that's not all! Mrs Kieffer also complains that we have collected sensitive data about her!
I saw that! Explain to me what exactly is sensitive data?!
Basically it is data that we have ,generally, no right to process!
Could you be more precise?

Sure, it would be best if you looked for information on the CNPD website.

They have a very useful webLevel 1 - Page on that subject.
Ok, I see there are afterall a lot of exceptions to that prohibition in principle.

Yes, but if you look closely at the list, what she's accusing us of, namely registering her bank card when making an online purchase, doesn't feature among the sensitive data according to the GDPR!

It is indeed data that needs to be protected, but we do this thanks to the security mechanisms on our servers...
Ouf ! So if I understand correctly, this is a problem that is none!
No indeed, this is not a problem of sensitive data administration!
So how  about I treat us to lunch to celebrate!?

Dominique will now proceed to delete Mrs Kieffer's data, send her a final email and inform Jeanine.

He is pleased to have succeeded in meeting the deadlines for access and deletion requests.

The threat of a penalty has therefore receded for LuxXport.

Mrs Kieffer's data had not been deleted by the former LuxXport sales representative, even though it was clearly out of date.

What's more, he was collecting far too much information.

Dominique says to himself that thanks to Bruno's common sense, who is much more conscientious, such mistakes will not happen again and he can rest easy about complying with the GDPR... on these subjects.

Dominique took advantage of the knowledge he had acquired and the good understanding of data flows he had acquired when preparing the response to the customer's requests to draw up a register of LuxXport's processing activities.

He knows that he will still have to document data management and draw up his information notices to comply with the obligation of accountability and transparency, in order to bring his company into line with the GDPR.

I'd never heard of this terrace!

Thank you, Jeanine, for introducing me to it…

The sun is out and the food is excellent!
Just like everywhere else in Luxembourg...

Apart from that, congratulations!
You handled those rights applications really well!
Thanks for the praise, but next time I'll be better prepared!

I'm sure of that !

But that just goes to show the value of internal procedures and routines: once they've been established, all you have to do is implement them!

To achieve this, you need good organisation and motivated employees.

And that's the case at my company!
Thank you for the compliment!
In fact, it's got me thinking that I need to write my privacy policy for my next website…
So now you've become GDPR responsible!
I'm working on it, but there is still some work to do.
I'm convinced you're goint to get there quickly!
With the help of the CNPD certainely! There's nothing like transparent procedures to keep customers' trust and loyalty!
I can go on holiday then with peace of mind!
Dominique speaks with LuxXport's administrative assistant, Judith.

Dominique Schummer, manager of the company LuxXport, wants to create a website in order to improve the visibility of his company and to allow his customers to shop online.

He asks Judith, his administrative assistant, to make an appointment with Mrs, Pria Boodhun, his solicitor, in order to be advised on the terms and conditions that will need to be published on the website at launch.

After this discussion, Judith hands him the mail which includes a letter from an attorney, Mr. Gilles Mertens.
It's a complaint letter by an employee, Mrs. Régina Fischer.

Judith schedules a meeting between Dominique and Mrs. Boodhun in order to discuss both questions.
Hello Judith, how are you?

Hello Dominique!

It feels like a Monday, if you allow my expression, with the usual slow traffic on the A4.
I desperately need a coffee …

Hang in there!

Maybe this will cheer you up: I have decided to go with your idea to create a website.
By the way, I will need you to make me an appointment with our solicitor, Mrs Pria Boodhun so that she can advise me on the terms and conditions that we will have to publish on our website.
Consider it done! I'll do it as soon as I've opened the mail!
15 minutes later
Dominique, apart from the usual mail, there's a stamped letter form a solicitor, Mr Gilles Mertens!

Really? I'll have a look at it right away!
Look at that, Mr. Mertens defends the interests of Mrs. Régina Fischer, our warehouse worker.
Apparently she's really unhappy!

Well, I guess I'll have an additional point to discuss with our solicitor!
Let me remind you that your appointment is tomorrow morning at 10!
Good Morning!
Good Morning, Mr. Schummer! Can I offer you a coffee?
Gladly! Black, without sugar!
So you finally decided to launch your website?

You have to go with the times!
On a different note, here is a letter by your colleague Mr. Gilles Mertens. Please have a look and let me know how to react.
I really need your advice!
Apparently it is about a delicate matter with regard to labour law and data protection …

This is about personal data? What a coincidence! 
I have just finished my record of processing activities using the template provided by the CNPD.
Very good! Let me address the issue of data protection in the context of a professional relationship then, a very vast topic!

Please don't use too many complicated words, I've only started to understand the basics…

Ah, thank you for the coffee!

Ok, let's go!

First of all your employee really doesn't hold back!

She says that your attitude towards her has deteriorated and that you even threatened her with dismissal!

Really?! I have often noticed her absence from her work station, which could have led to some harsh words towards her!

However, I have never threatened her with dismissal!
According to her, your attitude is unjustified and can be explained by her recent joining of a union…
I didn't know that at all! I think that is absolutely her right!
You have to know that union membership status is considered sensitive data, and that according to the GDPR, such data cannot be processed by an employer.
Yes, I've learned that at my expense after a customer's request for erasure… customer that actually wasn't one anymore. Well, long live the GDPR!
Very good! But you have to know that for every rule, even in the legal sphere, there are exceptions…
Really? I really would like to know which ones! Because I have to know everything inside out!

Without going to much into detail, the employer can process sensitive data if:

The data subject has given their explicit consent or has made the data public themselves. It is also the case for vital reason or in case of any legal action concerning the data subject.

Certain important public interest grounds can also be an exception.

Last but not least, sensitive data can also be processed for scientific, historical, statistical or archival research grounds.
But be careful! As is the case with customers, employees and suppliers have to be informed about any data processing concerning their data!
Customers, employees, suppliers… when will it ever stop?

Sorry, but where the right to information is concerned, the GDPR makes no exceptions in a professional setting!
Which means that everybody needs to be informed about the processing of their data.
You have to be transparent!

So with regard to my personal phone book, do I also have to be transparent with my friends and family?
Because it contains some of their personal data!

No, here the GDPR is clear: it is not applicable to a person in a purely private and domestic setting without any link to a professional or commercial activity.
So, no need to worry about our friends' and family's data, the rules don't apply here.
Phew! Finally I think the GDPR is logical and makes sense!

See? This common sense has to come into play from the signing of the work contract on! 
In fact the right to information of employees implies that they have to be informed at that moment of the data processing activities concerning them, namely the identity of the controller, the purposes of processing, the identity of the data recipients, the data retention period, their rights concerning their data, etc.

And, unfortunately, I can't detect any clause to that effect in the work contract of the employee in question. You'll have to address that for all your current and future employees either by a specific clause or by an information notice included in the work contract or any other space accessible to your employees.
Thank you for your advice! I will address these issues right away!
As with respect to the other point raised by Mr. Mertens, the possibility of a professional legal dispute is still real!
You know me I'm not a fan of proceedings.. I'd like to avoid that.
I understand! After your mishap with your former customer, you are currently totally up to date about data subjects' rights and subsequently about the right to access?
Yes, and?
I prefer to warn you that employees have a tendency to exercise that right in case of litigation…
So, if I understand correctly, in case of litigation, I'm compelled to help the employee who wants to harm me by giving them access to their personal data…
Exactly! In case of litigation, the employer has to conform with the right to access whoever the person!
You're worrying me! Please reassure me, do I have to expect other reactions from my employee?
Not really! In my experience, there are two categories: Those who ask for access to the totality of their personal data and those that are targeting a specific document.
Very good! I will have to adapt my answer accordingly!
Yes, and that's not all! Some documents may reference other employees…
Hello Dominique! How did your appointment with Mrs. Boodhun go?
Very good I'd say! I learned a lot about data protection in the professional context. For example, I know now that an employer has to respond to a request for access, even in case of litigation!
I already knew that, because during my studies at the University of Luxembourg they mentioned this point!

Judith, you would make an excellent DPO - or rather an excellent referent for data protection! Anyway Mrs. Boodhun will reply to Mr. Mertens letter by explaining that I'm not unhappy at all with Mrs. Fischer because she's now a union member but because of her repeated and regular absences from her work station, which I have pointed out to her on multiple occasions!
Dominique, have you already read Mrs. Boodhun's email that she sent yesterday evening?
No, I haven't had time yet! I have to meet with a sales representative about our cloud project this morning. Is there anything urgent in that e-mail?
In fact, according to our solicitor, Mrs. Fischer had a very strong reaction to the reply by Mrs. Boodhun, and is accusing LuxXport of multiple GDPR violations!
What kind of violations?
To name only one, our access badges apparently divulge too much information.
Ok for the badges, I didn't see the problem. Nonetheless it makes sense, we will rectify this.
Very good, but that's not all…she….
What? What else is she accusing us of?
Particularly the disproportionate use of the national identification number on our employees' meal vouchers.

Ohh, those meal vouchers! What a bonus for employees in Luxembourg! But it is indeed an interesting topic where the principal of minimisation should come into play! Could you please make some inquiries? I don't have the time!
After reflection and analysing the CNPD's HR recommendations by Judith:
Dominique, according to the CNPD, only information that is strictly necessary should be processed.
Ok, understood! I bet she also criticizes us for using her picture in our internal messaging system?
How did you guess?

Well, I'm starting to understand the principles of the GDPR! I still think it is nice to be able to see the face of the person you are dealing with inside of our company! So what is she accusing us of?
Well, according to the GDPR, the principal of purpose, minimization and consent haven't been respected in this case.
Well then….
We should have asked for her explicit consent in order to use her picture!
So we'll have to do that for all of our employees! Please tell me Judith that this is the end of her complaints….
Sorry, but no! To finish in style, she accuses you of monitoring her movements!
This is the height! Well talking about movements, I have to leave for my appointment. We'll continue talking when I'm back..
I'll use that time to re-read the CNPD's guidelines. If I remember correctly they have a brochure about geolocation…
Judith re-reads Mrs Fischer's last accusations and looks up the part of the CNPD's website pertaining to these points.

So let's get back to that letter…Mrs. Fischer accuses us of unjustly monitoring her movements.

What do the CNPD's recommendations say about geolocation…

Well they're pretty clear concerning the legal basis, it's legitimate interest and legal obligation.
Finally, Mrs. Fischer accuses LuxXport of modifying her working hours based on the geolocation data provided by the company car, instead of limiting themselves to the data stored by her badge.

Upon his return, Dominique Schummer reads the letter by Mr. Mertens and is outraged by the accusations against the company. He intends to reply in his own way by proving with pictures and videos that Mrs. Fischer is not irreproachable.

He hopes to make an end to the employees criticisms...

Is it a good idea? In any case Mr. Schummer seems to think so!

Siiiiiir, Mr. Mertens has contacted us directly about some pictures and videos we are supposed to have taken of Mrs. Fischer! She's exaggerating! Please reassure me that we are not carrying out any surveillance !?
No, of course not at all! Hu, ...I've to admit I reacted too spontaneously to Mr. Mertens' letter, without consulting with Mrs. Boodhun or you…..
How? You replied without talking to anybody first…?
Well, it's nothing… just some pictures and videos of her workstation from which she was absent …
DAT ASS SCHLËMM! She plagues us on all sides now by talking about an illegal video surveillance system!
I can understand your criticism! But let's remain calm and prepare the answer to her solicitor…
After discussion and reading the CNPD's recommendations, we believe that the record of processing activities needs to contain at least one entry relating to the CCTV system.
Judith, could you please put that entry into our records?
Sure! Consider it done!
This point having been taken care of, let's look more closely at Mrs. Fischer's accusations in Mr. Merten's letter.
Firstly, she accuses the company, as data controller, of not respecting the initial purposes of the CCTV system.
To me the purpose is clear: the system is there in order to protect our goods, notably our state of the art IT equipment, that's very expensive and to secure the access to our premises.
Well, that's the problem! Mr. Mertens argues that we can't use the pictures to sanction an employee.
And that's an absolute principle, is it?
Well, opinions differ according to the situation, it's a case by case situation. In order to see more clearly I will make an appointment with Mrs. Boodhun so you can discuss this point!
I have to admit that sending the pictures was quite foolish on my behalf!

Yes, especially without talking to me….we weren't in a hurry! 
But let's get on… according to the CNPD's guidelines, the camera's field of vision is problematic. Mrs. Fischer is constantly being filmed and her face isn't blacked out or blurred!

On that subject, the guidelines indicate that the processing is disproportionate as soon as you constantly film an employee.
So I only have to remove that camera or change its field of view so that Mrs. Fischer isn't filmed anymore.

Exactly! Hence that camera wouldn't be a problem according to the GDPR anymore!

By the way, what do we to do about the cameras that monitor the vicinity of our buildings?
I checked the field of vision of the external cameras on the monitor and the 3 cameras that monitor the surroundings are GDPR compliant. Is this all or does Mrs. Fischer have other complaints?
No, not really a complaint, but like our former customer Charlotte Kieffer, Mrs. Ficher would like to exercise her right to erasure.
That right I know very well and I know it is not absolute!
Indeed, a number of expectations are provided by the GDPR…

Dominique Schummer receives a letter by his solicitor Mrs. Boodhun.

Synopsis: "Dear Mr. Schummer! Mr. Mertens tells me that your employee Mrs. Fischer doesn't want to push on. She explains her absences by the stress brought on by the CCTV system that was continuously monitoring her.

She hopes that your working relationship can go back to normal.

For this to happen, she simply asks you to comply with the data protection rules so that she doesn't feel under surveillance at her workstation anymore."

Reaction to the letter: Mr. Schummer is glad to be able to put this incident behind him as he has many other things to do, for example the drafting of the information notice on the CCTV system, as well as the development of his website.

An agreement has been signed, litigation avoided and both parties are happy with the outcome.

Dominique Schummer is happy to be able to devote more time to his other obligations resulting from the GDPR, notably CCTV surveillance and the development of the company's website. He's preparing a basic privacy policy before meeting with Mrs. Boodhun.

Judith, you're more and more becoming an expert on data protection…. By the way, I think you are the best suited to accompany me in the implementation of our "respect for personal data" company strategy!
Thank you for the praise, Dominique, but I like to think it's normal that I do what I can! It's a field that I'm really interested in, because I highly value my privacy and that of my children!

I want you to know that I value our GDPR strategy more and more, because it can be a strong marketing argument for our company! And so, as we've discussed I want to respect customers', employees' and suppliers' right to information.

Firstly, could you please draft an understandable information notice for all of these subjects?

Of course! However the drafting of such a data protection notice has to respect certain criteria! Therefore I will write it in a clear and understandable language, even for a 10 year old child… That's even a solicitor's technique!
Judith drafts the information note catered towards the customers concerning the CCTV surveillance

I think I can do it by using the CNPD's CCTV guidelines. 
By the way, what do they say about this subject?

"All data controllers shall be obliged to inform data subjects about the processing of personal data which it carries out. This information must meet the requirements of Articles 12 and 13 of the GDPR. In particular, it may be communicated by affixing billboards and pictograms in places subject to video surveillance, in addition to a more detailed information note published, for example, on the website of the controller..."

Therefore, by complying with those recommendations, Judith intends to put in place a two-tiered information system with regard to "video surveillance" processing. This lends itself particularly well to this processing.
Hello Judith? I've re-read your information note on "video surveillance" applied to customers and I think that's exactly it!

Thank you very much Dominique! However, that is not all. For the note to be complete, other processing operations still need to be mentioned and explained, such as billing, loyalty card, to name but a few.
Do you think you could have a draft ready for each of our clients' personal data processing operations before the meeting with Mrs. Boodhun?
Of course! I can keep on writing by trying to be as complete as possible concerning the specific information about the processing of customer's data.

It's the big day, Mrs. Boodhun visits LuxXport in order to outline the terms and conditions of the future website, and especially to finalise the content of the information notes and the cookie policy…
Hello Mr. Schummer! First of all let me thank Mrs. Rossi and you for all the information that you provided. That was a good basis and helped me to prepare all of the information notes.
Hello Mrs. Boodhun! Before we start reviewing the information notes can I offer you a coffee?
Gladly! You had boasted so much about your coffee!

There you go, organic and Fairtrade!

I'm eager to read the information notes that you're proposing! After that, we can move on the terms and conditions and the cookie policy!

About that, do you have any idea about the features and statistics you want to set up?
The nature of the cookies will depend on it: in fact there are two big categories of cookies, those so-called essential and those that are called non-essential.

Pavel, our IT expert, has explained to me the difference between these two categories by insisting a lot on the purposes of the cookies and he cautioned me against use of third party cookies, especially those of social media networks.
Did he also mention the need to obtain the consent of website's visitor for the use of non-essential cookies?
Of course, and by the way these cookies will be an integral part of our marketing strategy and improvement of our commercial offer!
To summarize, the site will allow for the use of essential and non-essential cookies.
That's it!
Consequently I will prepare a policy that will detail the purposes, the duration and the complete list of cookies.
That's great! And Pavel will take care of the "cookie" banner in order to collect the prior consent of the website's users, if I understand correctly?
Yes, about that, I can only recommend him to read the CNPD's guideline on cookies. This guideline illustrates and informs perfectly about valid banners!

Judith and Pavel manage together to finalize the last patches of the website.

Pavel published the privacy policy and the cookie policy prepared by Mrs. Boodhun. The banners that have been implemented according to the cookie guideline of the CNPD are operational.

Dominique is now very happy to have a website that is compliant with the GDPR and looks forward to the potential and visibility it will bring to the company.

Mrs P. Boodhun, solicitor
Dominique Schummer, manager of LuxXport, has organized a summer seminar at the prestigious Vianden Castle, to which all his employees have been invited.

Before moving on to the more enjoyable part of the programme, team-building activities consisting of a treasure hunt through the medieval village of Vianden, he has gathered the employees in the castle's reception hall to present the new cloud system, that documents all the company's customers.

After the inaugural speech, Dominique heads towards the computer to start the presentation.

Whispers, incomprehension in the room… an error message has popped up!

The cloud is unavailable.

Please try again later.

Error Code 404.
Pavel, I need to pick your brain! Can you please fix this so that I can finish the presentation of the cloud?
After some verifications, Pavel makes the following report.

Boss, this is an error message related to the availability of our provider's servers and not to our equipment.

As you have chosen to outsource our customer data base, we now have to contact our provider and ask him to check his systems!

I'm fearing the worst! I'll contact them immediately hoping that our data remains intact!

Where is Judith?
I'm here, Dominique! What's going on, you seem worried!
What do we know about the information security for our data stored by our data processor in the cloud?

I will have a look at the service agreement in the hope that there is a clause referring to the GDPR.

In principle, the data processor has to respect the GDPR, just as the data controller does.
Dominique is on the phone with the cloud provider. Pavel calls out to him.
So Boss, what's happening? Everybody is curious to find out…

Pavel. I'm starting to lose patience! I have been trying to contact the processor for 30 minutes already and he's not picking up!

I have left a voice message and sent an e-mail but I fear that they are to busy fixing the system!
I can only see one explanation given the robustness of their servers …
Don't tell me that they have been the victim of a  cyberattack!
It's possible, but their servers also could have burned down!

In any case, this is as disaster for the future of the company. We need the advise of an expert in order to know how we should act.

Where is Judith?
I'm still here, Dominique!

Judith, given the circumstances I have decided to postpone the presentation of the cloud. 
Who can we contact if we've been the victim of a cyberattack?
If you say cyberattack, you mean an attack via internet carried out remotely by hackers?
Exactly. This is serious. If they have our customer data they will contact us pretty soon to demand a ransom!
Luxembourg is at the forefront in the area of cybersecurity! I'll get back to you with the contact details of the organizations to contact in case of a cyberattack.
The morning after the incident, Dominique Schummer is finally contacted by the cloud provider.

Hey Judith!

How are you?

I have made us a cup of coffee! The boss still hasn't left his office!
That's not like him! He never misses his morning coffee! Since I've arrived his phone line has been busy. I hope he now knows more about the incident.
Dominique leaves his office and passes by his coffee without saying a word.
Boy, oh, Boy... in 5 years I've never seen him like that!
Dominique comes back looking dismayed and turns to Pavel and Judith
Unfortunately, Pavel, you have been right! There has been an incident!
And our customer data, did it go up in smoke?
The processor has been clear, it's dead! He asks me to prepare a data breach notification for the CNPD.
I will try to get some information about the nature of the data breach before starting to fill out the CNPD form. In any case, it looks like a complete unavailability!
Thank you two for your help! At the moment this is all we can do to not make the situation worse.
What about your coffee?

Boss, I have been able to restore our old information system. Our CRM as well as our Access Data base are intact.

The loss of data is limited to our new customers.
Finally some good news! The only downside is that the data loss impacts the two big contracts that we've just signed.

Yes, but at least from a GDPR standpoint, the problem didn't come from our end! 
So do we postpone this operation till an in-house back-up has been done?
I'll have to talk about it with Judith, because I'm asking myself who has to notify the CNPD of the data breach, me or the data processor …
To me, it seems clear: they want us to do their job for them!
It's not as simple as that! I am the data controller of the impacted data after all.
Judith Rossi visits the CNPD website in order to download the data breach notification form.
Dominique, I've filled out as clearly and detailed as possible the CNPD's online form "data breach". However, we have to review the newest facts in order to finalise it.
I'll have a look at it on my end and complete it by the end of the week.
Be careful Dominique, there is a deadline and we have only 24 hours left to notify the CNPD.

Can we sent it to the CNPD without it being complete, because I am not certain I will have more information within the next 24 hours?

Our cloud provider has merely informed me that they will recontact me within the week, as soon as they know more.

Apparently, the incident is being handled higher up within the group!
That's not all: We also have to identify the customers whose personal data we have lost and inform them, as soon as possible!
Ok, I will immediately contact the data processor to remind them of their obligations in case of a data breach.
Hello Judith! Tell me, you're up early today!
There was hardly any traffic on the motorway… tell me, were you able to have a look at the form?
Yes, I already sent it to the CNPD this morning with all the information that we currently have in order to comply with the 72 hour deadline!
And you said I had an early morning… In any case, it's good that that's done even if we have to add to the form later on!
Indeed, at this stage we have covered our backs by filing this preliminary data breach notification.
The next day:
Hello Dominique, how are you?
I'm already on my second coffee. I haven't been sleeping well since the incident! Any news from the CNPD or the provider?
No news from the cloud provider. On the other hand, after their acknowledgement of receipt from yesterday, have sent us an e-mail this morning. Here, read for yourself!

Dominique is reading the e-mail " The CNPD understands that the breach only concerns new customers and we would be grateful if you could:

Specify the seriousness of the breach in terms of the risk to the rights and freedoms of individuals and, where appropriate, whether or not it is necessary to contact the customers concerned.

Describe the measures you have taken or intend to take to remedy the data breach."
In his office, Dominique is reading the CNPD's e-mail in the company of Judith.

At the moment, I have no idea how serious the incident is in relation to the rights and freedoms of our new customers.

As far as I know, it is limited to business contracts linked to the purchase of our printers,  for which I assume we don't process sensitive data.
We have to be sure, because our notification obligations vary whether the incident seriously impacts or not, our customers.

Really? Thank you Judith, I didn't know about that subtlety of the GDPR!

So, what do we have to do in case of a not so serious risk to our customer's rights and freedoms?

Let's summarize:

As far as notification within 72 hours is concerned, we're good!

As far as documenting the breach is concerned, I suggest we take our inspiration from the recently introduced register of processing activities and adapt it to create a register of data breaches.

Alternatively, could you tell me what to do in the event of a serious risk impacting our customers' rights and freedoms?
We need to inform them individually. This with the aim to help them to protect themselves from potential consequences.

Protect them from what? Can you give me a practical example?

I find it difficult to understand, after all this is only commercial data!
Commercial data that enables to identify directly or indirectly the customer! Therefore personal data!

But more precisely, admitting that we are processing personal data, what does the CNPD mean by:

" Describe the measures taken or intend to take to remedy the data beach"?

We're going to have to notify, because it's not too obvious!

These are measures to be implemented on a case-by-case basis depending on the incident that caused the "data breach", in order to guarantee enhanced security for personal data and therefore to prevent such an incident from happening again.
I see, I see… our data processor has got their work cut out for them!
Certainly, but the data controller to the customer, that's you Dominique!
Me? I know that, but I can't correct our supplier's technical and organisational problems for him! Can I?

Of course not, but unfortunately your responsibility in data protection matters can't be transferred, together with the data to our cloud provider.

From now on we will have to think about mitigating the risks ourselves.
So do we keep everything as it is and store everything internally?
An in-house back-up would be a good idea. We also have to make sure that the data is anonymised, pseudonymised or encrypted on our servers.

So  lot of work in our future.

But we can't avoid it if I understand correctly!

Exactly, Dominique!

In fact, we have to prove to the CNPD that we reacted accordingly in relation to the scope of the problem.

I'll have to discuss all of this with Pavel and Bruno!

From now on we have to better anticipate the risks and take the appropriate security measures.

I will personally make this one of our goals for this year!
The next day, Pavel and Bruno are called to a meeting
Good morning the two of you.
Hello Dominique!
Good morning, boss! To what do we owe this impromptu meeting?
As a consequence of the incident that you are well aware off, I would like to install a back-up and put in place a mechanism to anonymise and encrypt our customer data.

What a brilliant idea!

With the anonymised customer data we can create statistics that can help us improve our offer of goods and services. We could even use them in the context of an AI system without any GDPR restrictions!

Hence, the commercial potential we could gain from this could be huge for the company!

Which goes to show that an incident like that can indeed be a godsend.

Pavel can you please get back to me with a feasibility study?

Consider it done, boss!

Anonymisation, encryption and AI, 3 dream subjects for the IT geek that I am!

Dominique Schummer tests the cloud service again!

To his surprise the system is operational again!

He feels something between joy and incomprehension.

After this he fills out the additional form that informs about the absence of any risk for the customer's rights and freedoms, as well as the mitigating measures put in place.

The data beach is not characterized by a loss of data , but by a temporary unavailability of customer data.

Judith, you will never guess what I just learned from our cloud provider!

I really need a coffee now, meet me in the coffee corner.
What happened? You look concerned!

All that turmoil these last few days was for nothing…

Our cloud provider has told me that our data has been found when one of their foreign subsidiaries performed an automated back-up of all of their servers.

But that's not included in the contract!

We've never talked about it!
Exactly, the provider seems to do a lot more with our data than planned….and it even happens abroad!
What abroad? It's true that there is a lot of talk about India at the moment, a country that doesn't have  data protection considered equal to that of the European Union!
Our cloud provider couldn't tell me.. He doesn't know in what country their secondary servers are, but he doubts that it is in the greater Luxembourg region, otherwise he would have heard about it!

Hello Dominique!

Listen, concerning the countries that our data might have gone to.. After a bit of research I've found an interesting list on the website of the EDPB, the CNPD for the European institutions and it will put your mind at ease!
Let's go, I'm curious to know what you 've found out!
I didn't know this but the European Commission regularly carries out audits of other countries' legislation!
So, what does this have to do with us?
Well there a number of countries that have an adequation decision by the Commission!

Equation, adequation…I've never been any good at maths!

I don't understand what you're trying to tell me!
My point is that those countries have laws similar to the GDPR and, therefore, transfers to those countries are free!
That's great! We have to hope that the back-up servers that host our data are in one of those countries!
In principle yes, because that means less legal constraints for multinational companies.

Ahh there you are, I've been looking for you Dominique!

I've just received an e-mail from the Philippines with the same logo as our cloud provider!

That's it, I'm going to faint!

Our data is at the other end of the world!

How can that be? We really have to go over our sub-processing contract!

No need to rush, all in good time!

We first have to find out what the GDPR requirements are in case of a data transfer to a country without an adequation decision…
According to the CNPD's website which I've skimmed through, there are standard contractual clauses, codes of conduct or even certificates … I have to admit I'm a bit in over my head!
Hey Judith, what are you doing here this early?

Good Morning, Dominique!

First of all I wanted to avoid the usual heavy traffic and secondly I have to leave earlier tonight and would like to finish my research on the measures to take in case of a data transfer to a "third country".

It's not that simple, at least six solutions are planned for in the GDPR!

But that's going to take us all day!

Please show  me.
Dominique reads the GDPR articles pertaining to "third country" transfers
Ohh God, I'm in trouble again!

As far as I understand we have to consider this on a case by case basis!

In our case the most adequate and common thing to do would be to sign a contract containing standard contractual clauses.
Can you manage without the help of Mrs. Boodhun?

At first glance I think I can manage.

I just have to select the contractual clauses template provided by the European Commission that best suits our case.

There are 4 different templates depending on the nature of the parties involved.

How about a coffee to give you a little boost?

I'll go get one and bring it to you!

A boss that serves his employee coffee!

The world has turned upside down!
A little bit later in the afternoon

Judith, I have had a call from our cloud provider!

Apparently all of our data is safe….
Really? Safe in the Philippines….
Well no! Go figure our data never went to the Philippines, they have always been stored on a server in Switzerland.
Great! Especially since Switzerland seems to have an equal level of protection to the GDPR.
It's true that where data protection is concerned Switzerland is a vault!
Boss…

Sorry, I couldn't resist…

But let's circle back: the cloud provider has clarified that all the entities of the group have to comply with binding corporate rules!

Of course, I pretended to understand what that means...
I think he wanted to talk about "BCR"!
BCR???

Dominique is finally satisfied that the customer data has been transferred to a backup server in a country that has a decision of adequation by the European Commission. This doesn't require any additional measure in regard to GDPR compliance.

Dominique nonetheless is determined to sign a processing contract as the incident has shown a certain number of "failures" in the data handling by the data processor.
A  little later in the afternoon
Our cloud provider gets off lightly after all these twists and turns...
That's so true! Luckily they made the effort to be "GDPR compliant"!

Exactly, talking about "compliance"!

As I didn't now what they were doing with our customer data, I broke out in cold sweats a few times!

In order to avoid that in the future, I would like to better frame the data processing done by our providers.
In that case we will have to review all of our service contracts and insure that in case of data processing our providers guarantee a protection equal to the GDPR.
Absolutely! But how can we do that? We don't have the means to monitor that, we are only a small company!

Rest reassured it will not be very costly for us!

I will prepare an outsourcing contract on the basis of article 28 of the GDPR and propose to our partners to sign them in case their contract doesn't seem complete.

But after all the mistake still happened with the cloud provider!

So I think he should be the one to assume all of the responsibility! I will have to check that…

Judith told me about some websites where I can find all the information we need on data protection.

Tell me Judith, I didn't expect there would be that many obligations in case of outsourcing of data processing!

You really went to the bottom of this!

You think? In fact the standard contractual clauses provided by the European Commission leave nothing to chance when it comes to framing the obligations of all the parties involved in a sub processing contract, believe it or not!

I can tell that you got your information from the right sources!

That's excellent!
After reading the contract I fell a lot more up to date in matters of data protection!
What makes you say that?
I'm not worried anymore that our data could be transferred to a third party by our partners without my consent, for example!
That's the whole point of framing the sub-processing of data!
However it's more than a frame! You have nailed everything down!
What do you mean by that?

On top of that, there are a lot of annexes and even one that is specific to the description of the data processing!

Do we have to fill all of this out?
That's the whole point of framing the sub-processing of data!
Stop repeating yourself Judith! I just realized that there is nothing about the security of data!

Wait…Ah yes, I didn't say anything!

I've just become aware of annexe 3 on technical and organisational matters! This time, I will repeat myself: you've really nailed everything down!
Still not enough yet….
What? But you're going to make our partners run!
That's the whole point of framing the sub-processing of data!
But stop repeating yourself, it's business first!

I'm only joking Dominique!

In fact, these provisions will only attest to your seriousness, which will in turn reassure our customers…

And besides, we have to clear the air with our cloud provider after our latest adventures!

He did a lot to us: fire, data breach, non-contractual back-up, etc...

Well, let's get back to serious matters! I'm asking myself if I can add a specific clause to the contract, that would force the processor to inform us about any data breach...

Dominique is proud of the steps completed and the progress made.

The management of the data breach has been a success and  gave  the opportunity to test his reflexes in the event of a data breach.

The data transfer to a third country proved to be simpler than he imagined with the cloud provider and gave him the opportunity to better frame the sub-processing of personal data.

The customer data is safe now.

Together with Judith, Dominique has planned to schedule a training session in the short run for his employees in order to make them aware of the GDPR measures taken.

Finally a new presentation on the new customer data management via cloud with a local back-up cold took place in the Vianden Castle.

The technical and organisational measures have been improved by the data processor.

The processor now only processes encrypted data, for which the encryption key is being held by LuxXport, and, as a technical measure, has implemented a double back-up.
Pavel

Que doit contenir ce document ?
Parmi les scénarios suivants lesquels constituent un consentement licite selon le RGPD ?

Veuillez sélectionner le droit correspondant à la description suivante:  Si la conservation de certaines données concernant une personne n’est plus justifiée ou est inutile, cette personne peut demander leur suppression. En effet, si le responsable du traitement n’a plus aucun motif légitime (p.ex : des obligations légales au niveau de la comptabilité) qui justifie la conservation des données, ces données doivent être supprimées.

Veuillez sélectionner le droit correspondant à la description suivante: La personne concernée peut revendiquer ce droit, si elle conteste l’exactitude d’une donnée (le temps de la vérification par l’entreprise), si le traitement est illicite, préférant une telle limitation au lieu de l’effacement ou si la personne en a besoin pour la constatation, l'exercice ou la défense de ses droits en justice.

Veuillez sélectionner le droit correspondant à la description suivante: La personne concernée à le droit de savoir pourquoi et comment ses données personnelles sont utilisées. La réponse à ce droit doit se présenter dans un langage simple et clair au moment même de la collecte des données ou si les données n’ont pas été collectées auprès de la personne elle-même, dans un délai raisonnable ne dépassant pas un mois.

Veuillez sélectionner le droit correspondant à la description suivante: La personne concernée a le droit de contester à tout moment un traitement des données à caractère personnel nécessaire à la poursuite des intérêts légitimes du responsable du traitement ou à l’exécution d’une mission d’intérêt public, y compris le profilage. Elle doit mettre en avant « des raisons tenant à sa situation particulière », sauf en cas de prospection commerciale, à laquelle elle peut exercer ce droit sans motif.

Veuillez sélectionner le droit correspondant à la description suivante: Si vous prenez des décisions relatives à l’approbation d’une demande de crédit de consommation de manière automatisée, vous devez accorder aux personnes la possibilité de faire valoir leur point de vue et de contester, le cas échéant, la décision.

Veuillez sélectionner le droit correspondant à la description suivante: Une personne concernée doit pouvoir récupérer les données qu’elle a communiquées à un organisme (dans un format structuré, couramment utilisé et lisible par machine) et les transmettre à un autre (réseau social, fournisseur d’accès à Internet, site de streaming, etc.).

Veuillez sélectionner le droit correspondant à la description suivante: Si une personne exerce ce droit, vous devez lui communiquer une copie de l’intégralité des données que vous possédez à son sujet.

Veuillez sélectionner le droit correspondant à la description suivante: Si la personne concernée a remarqué que des données qui la concernent sont inexactes, incomplètes ou tout simplement plus à jour, elle a la possibilité de formuler ce droit pour éviter qu’un organisme ne traite ou diffuse de fausses informations sur elle.

Please select the right corresponding to the following description: A data subject must be able to retrieve the data they have communicated to one organisation (in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format) and transmit it to another (social network, internet service provider, streaming site, etc.).
Please select the right corresponding to the following description: If a person exercises this right, you must provide them with a full copy of the data you hold about them.

Depuis le 25 mai 2018, Le Règlement Général sur la Protection des Données (RGPD) est applicable. Le RGPD vise principalement à donner aux individus le contrôle de leurs données à caractère personnel et demande aux entreprises qui gèrent des données de:
  • justifier la collecte et la conservation des données personnelles;
  • assurer leur sécurité et leur confidentialité;
  • informer les personnes concernées sur leurs droits (modification, suppression, portabilité des données…); et
  • nommer un délégué à la protection des données dans certains cas.

Le RGPD s'applique :
  • aux organismes établis sur le territoire de l'Union européenne, que le traitement ait lieu ou non dans l'UE
  • aux organismes situés hors UE, dont l'activité cible des personnes qui se trouvent sur le territoire de l'UE.
Le RGPD s'applique à tous les organismes remplissant ces conditions, qu’ils soient publics, privés et quelle que soit leur taille ou leur secteur d'activité.

Le Délégué à la Protection des Données (DPD ou en anglais DPO : Data Protection Officer) a comme missions principales :
  • d’informer et conseiller l’organisme concernant la mise en œuvre du RGPD
  • de contrôler la conformité
  • d’être un point de contact entre l’organisme, la CNPD et les personnes concernées

Par « données à caractère personnel », on entend toute information concernant une personne physique identifiée ou identifiable. 

Une « personne physique identifiable » est définie comme une personne physique qui peut être identifiée, directement ou indirectement, notamment par référence à un identifiant, tel qu’un nom, un numéro d’identification, des données de localisation, un identifiant en ligne ou un ou plusieurs éléments spécifiques de son identité physique, physiologique, génétique, psychologique, économique, culturelle ou sociale.

Selon l’article 4 du RGPD : 

« Est un traitement toute opération ou ensemble d'opérations effectuées ou non à l'aide de procédés automatisés et appliquées à des données ou des ensembles de données à caractère personnel [...] »,

La collecte, l’extraction, l’enregistrement, la conservation, la modification mais également la consultation de données à caractère personnel sont donc des traitements.

L’objectif majeur du RGPD est de renforcer le contrôle des individus sur leurs données. 
Le droit d’accès évoqué dans cette question permet à l’individu de savoir si des données le concernant sont traitées et d’en obtenir la communication dans un format compréhensible.

Lorsque vous êtes confrontés à la demande d’une personne souhaitant exercer ses droits, la vérification de son identité est essentielle.

Le niveau de vérification requis peut varier en fonction de la nature de la demande, de l'importance des informations communiquées et du contexte spécifique de la demande. 
Par principe, il faut éviter de demander une copie de la carte d’identité de la personne car cette vérification d’identité peut être effectuée « par tout moyen ».

Par exemple, la personne concernée peut vous fournir des informations complémentaires telles qu'un numéro de client ou d'adhérent, afin de confirmer son identité. La personne peut également justifier de son identité en exerçant ses droits depuis un espace où elle s’est préalablement authentifiée.

Toutefois, en cas de « doute raisonnable » concernant l'identité d'une personne, vous pouvez lui demander de fournir d'autres documents permettant de confirmer son identité dont une copie de la carte d’identité.

Lorsqu’une personne exerce son droit d’accès, le responsable de traitement doit lui fournir une copie des données la concernant ainsi que les informations suivantes :
  • les finalités du traitement;
  • les catégories de données à caractère personnel concernées;
  • les destinataires ou catégories de destinataires auxquels les données à caractère personnel ont été ou seront communiquées, en particulier les destinataires qui sont établis dans des pays tiers ou les organisations internationales;
  • lorsque cela est possible, la durée de conservation des données à caractère personnel envisagée ou, lorsque ce n'est pas possible, les critères utilisés pour déterminer cette durée;
  • l'existence du droit de demander au responsable du traitement la rectification ou l'effacement de données à caractère personnel, ou une limitation du traitement des données à caractère personnel relatives à la personne concernée, ou du droit de s'opposer à ce traitement;
  • le droit d'introduire une réclamation auprès d'une autorité de contrôle;
  • lorsque les données à caractère personnel ne sont pas collectées auprès de la personne concernée, toute information disponible quant à leur source;
  • l'existence d'une prise de décision automatisée, y compris un profilage, visée à l'article 22, paragraphes 1 et 4 du RGPD, et, au moins en pareil cas, des informations utiles concernant la logique sous-jacente, ainsi que l'importance et les conséquences prévues de ce traitement pour la personne concernée.
Enfin, lorsque les données à caractère personnel sont transférées vers un pays tiers ou à une organisation internationale, la personne concernée doit également être informée des garanties appropriées, en vertu de l'article 46 du RGPD, en ce qui concerne ce transfert.

Comme pour toutes demandes exercées par une personne concernée, une réponse à une demande d’accès doit être fournie dans les meilleurs délais et en tout état de cause dans un délai d'un mois maximum à compter de la réception de la demande.  

Au besoin, ce délai peut être prolongé de deux mois, compte tenu de la complexité et du nombre de demandes. Dans ce cas, le responsable du traitement doit informer la personne concernée de cette prolongation et des motifs du report dans un délai d'un mois à compter de la réception de la demande.

L’organisme doit faciliter l’exercice des droits des individus concernés par le traitement des données. Il ne peut pas refuser de donner suite à une demande sans le justifier auprès de la personne. L’exercice du droit d’accès est en principe gratuit. L’organisme peut ne pas donner suite à une demande si :
  • sa mise en œuvre porte atteinte aux droits ou libertés d’autrui (notamment en ce qui concerne le secret des affaires, la propriété intellectuelle et les droits d’auteur protégeant un logiciel)
  • les demandes d'une personne sont manifestement infondées ou excessives, notamment en raison de leur caractère répétitif (dans ce cas, le responsable pourra, alternativement au refus de donner suite au droit d'accès, choisir d'y répondre en exigeant le paiement de frais raisonnables qui tiennent compte des coûts administratifs supportés pour fournir les informations, procéder aux communications ou prendre les mesures demandées).
Si l’organisme choisit de ne pas donner suite à la demande, il doit alors informer la personne concernée dans un délai d’un mois, en motivant son choix et en l’informant de la possibilité d’introduire une réclamation auprès de la CNPD et de former un recours juridictionnel.

Vous devez informer les personnes concernées que leurs données personnelles sont traitées, par qui et pourquoi. 

Cette information doit se présenter dans un langage simple et clair au moment même de la collecte des données ou si les données n’ont pas été collectées auprès de la personne elle-même, dans un délai raisonnable ne dépassant pas un mois. 

Ce droit est limité dans certains cas (p. ex. la sécurité publique ou la poursuite d’infractions pénales).

En exerçant son droit à l’oubli, un individu peut demander à un organisme l'effacement des données personnelles le concernant mais seulement dans l’une de ces six situations :
  • Les données ne sont plus nécessaires au regard des finalités pour lesquelles elles sont collectées ou traitées
  • la personne retire son consentement au traitement de ses données
  • la personne s’oppose au traitement et il n’existe pas de motif légitime impérieux
  • le traitement est illicite (ex : le traitement s’effectue en violation d’une disposition du code de la santé publique)
  • les données doivent être effacées pour respecter une obligation légale
  • les données ont été collectées auprès de mineurs dans le cadre de l’offre de services de la société de l’information.
Le droit à l’effacement ne peut pas s’appliquer s’il va à l’encontre :
  • de la liberté d’expression et d’information
  • du respect d’une obligation légale
  • d’un motif d’intérêt public dans le domaine de la santé publique
  • des fins archivistiques dans l’intérêt public, des fins statistiques, de recherche scientifique ou historique de la constatation, de l’exercice ou de la défense de droits en justice.

La finalité du traitement est l'objectif principal de l'utilisation de données personnelles. Les données sont collectées pour un but bien déterminé et légitime et ne doivent pas être traitées ultérieurement de façon incompatible avec cet objectif initial.

La finalité doit donc être : 

Déterminée : un objectif précis doit être déterminé avant la mise en œuvre du traitement

Explicite : la finalité est énoncée de manière compréhensive et suffisamment claire (à l'égard des personnes concernées).

Légitime : elle est remise en cause si la finalité du traitement est jugée peu justifiée ou trop intrusive.

Consentement de la personne concernée : 

Toute manifestation de volonté non contrainte par laquelle la personne concernée accepte, par une déclaration ou par un acte positif clair, que des données à caractère personnel la concernant fassent l'objet d'un traitement.

Note : Dans les cas où le traitement repose sur le consentement, le responsable du traitement est en mesure de démontrer que la personne concernée a donné son consentement oralement ou par écrit au traitement de données à caractère personnel la concernant.

Avant de traiter des données à caractère personnel, il vous faut identifier la base juridique sur laquelle se fonde votre traitement. Un traitement de données n’est licite que si au moins une des conditions suivantes est remplie :
  • La personne concernée a consenti au traitement de ses données à caractère personnel pour une ou plusieurs finalités spécifiques.
  • Le traitement est nécessaire à l’exécution d’un contrat auquel la personne concernée est partie ou à l’exécution de mesures précontractuelles prises à la demande de celle-ci.
  • Le traitement est nécessaire au respect d’une obligation légale (claire et précise) à laquelle le responsable du traitement est soumis.
  • Le traitement est nécessaire à la sauvegarde des intérêts vitaux de la personne concernée ou d’une autre personne physique.
  • Le traitement est nécessaire à l’exécution d’une mission d’intérêt public ou relevant de l’exercice de l’autorité publique dont est investi le responsable du traitement.
  • Le traitement est nécessaire aux fins des intérêts légitimes poursuivis par le responsable du traitement (p.ex. à des fins de marketing, anti-fraude, traitement des données clients ou salariés, sécurité des traitements, etc.).

De façon générale, le RGPD confère aux personnes concernées un droit de s’opposer (« opt-out ») au traitement de données à caractère personnel la concernant à des fins de prospection (p.ex. aux courriers de prospection envoyés par la poste). 

La loi luxembourgeoise modifiée du 30 mai 2005, qui continue à s’appliquer aux communications électroniques, dispose que le responsable du traitement (i.e. l’entreprise) est autorisé, dans le cas d'une base contractuelle déjà existante (vente ou services), à utiliser l'adresse e-mail de son client ou abonné à des fins publicitaires sans consentement préalable. 

En contrepartie, le client ou abonné doit avoir le droit de s’y opposer à tout moment (et être informé de ce droit lorsque les données sont recueillis et lors de chaque message de prospection).

Dans le cas où il n’existe aucun lien entre une entreprise (le responsable du traitement) et un utilisateur, le consentement préalable doit être demandé avant l’envoi de courriers électroniques (« opt-in »).

Le principe de minimisation des données implique que ne doivent être traitées que les données qui apparaissent strictement nécessaires pour atteindre la/les finalité(s) poursuivie(s) (« données adéquates, pertinentes et limitées à ce qui est nécessaire ») et que les opérations de traitement ne doivent pas être disproportionnées.

Par exemple, traiter seulement la tranche d'âge, ainsi que le jour et le mois de naissance au lieu d'une date de naissance complète pour un traitement relatif à l'attribution d'un cadeau de fidelité adapté à l'âge du client.

Données sensibles :  Il s’agit des traitements qui révèlent l'origine raciale ou ethnique, les opinions politiques, les convictions religieuses ou philosophiques ou l'appartenance syndicale, ainsi que le traitement des données génétiques, des données biométriques aux fins d'identifier une personne physique de manière unique, des données concernant la santé ou des données concernant la vie sexuelle ou l'orientation sexuelle d'une personne physique.

Les données bancaires, bien que constituant des données présentant un fort enjeu, ne sont pas considérées comme étant des données « sensibles » au sens du RGPD et ne dépendent donc pas des règles spécifiques de l’article 9 du RGPD auquel ces données sensibles sont soumises. Il convient cependant de respecter les autres obligations du RGPD concernant les informations bancaires et notamment les obligations de sécurité, de confidentialité et de minimisation.

La CNPD, l’autorité de protection des données du Luxembourg, pourra infliger des amendes pouvant atteindre un montant maximal de 20 millions d’euros ou correspondant à 4% du chiffre d’affaire annuel mondial total du responsable de traitement en cas de traitement en violation avec les dispositions du règlement.

Les amendes sont basées sur plusieurs facteurs, notamment : la nature de l’infraction, l’intention, les mesures prises pour atténuer les dommages causés aux personnes concernées, les mesures préventives en place, la coopération avec les autorités et le type de données.

En tant que responsable du traitement, vous devez tenir un registre des activités de traitement effectuées sous votre responsabilité. De même, chacun de vos sous-traitants doit tenir un registre de toutes les catégories d’activités de traitement effectuées pour votre compte.

En ce qui concerne le contenu du registre des traitements du sous-traitant, consultez la page internet de la CNPD sur le registre des activités de traitement.

Le RGPD ne définit pas de modèle ou de format unique de registre d’activités de traitement. Chaque responsable du traitement ou sous-traitant peut donc utiliser la forme qu’il souhaite, pourvu qu'y figurent les informations visées à l’article 30 du RGPD.

Depuis le processus de recrutement et après la fin de la relation de travail, l’employeur se trouve confronté à un nombre important de cas où il devra appliquer les règles relatives à la protection des données.
En effet, un employeur est souvent amené à collecter des données à caractère personnel, par exemple lorsqu’un candidat lui envoie son Curriculum Vitae, lorsqu’un salarié lui communique ses coordonnées bancaires pour qu’il puisse procéder au paiement de son salaire, lors des évaluations professionnelles annuelles de ses salariés, ou encore afin de rembourser des frais de route à un de ses salariés.
Il appartient à l’employeur de déterminer, avant tout traitement de données personnelles et au regard du contexte spécifique, quelle base de licéité est la plus appropriée et pourrait justifier le traitement envisagé. 
Il revient encore à l’employeur de documenter sa conformité au RGPD (principe d’« accountability » ou de responsabilisation). Cette documentation sera nécessaire pour le responsable du traitement, notamment en cas de contrôle par la CNPD ou quand les personnes concernées font usage de leurs droits.

Le traitement des données sensibles est interdit (Art. 9.1. RGPD), sauf si une des dix conditions prévues par l’article 9.2. du RGPD est applicable, à savoir:
  • Consentement explicite de la personne concernée.
  • Le traitement est nécessaire aux fins de l’exécution des obligations et de l’exercice des droits propres au responsable du traitement ou à la personne concernée en matière de droit du travail, de la sécurité sociale et de la protection sociale (condition : le traitement est autorisé par la loi ou par une convention collective).
  • Sauvegarde des intérêts vitaux.
  • Traitement des données rendues publiques par la personne concernée.
  • Action en justice.
  • Traitement par un organisme à but non lucratif poursuivant une finalité politique, philosophique, religieuse ou syndicale visant exclusivement les membres dudit organisme.
  • Motifs d’intérêt public important sur base du droit européen ou national qui prévoit des garanties appropriées.
