Any processing of personal data must be based on one of the conditions of lawfulness listed exhaustively in Article 6.1 of the GDPR. In the context of a geolocation device installed by an employer to monitor its employees, a valid condition of lawfulness could be that the processing is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests of the controller, unless the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the person(s) being geolocated prevail (Article 6.1. f) of the RGPD).
Furthermore, in the event that the installation of a geolocation device for employees' vehicles is imposed on the employer by a rule of national or European law (e.g. legislation applicable in the field of national and international road transport), the condition of compliance with a legal obligation could apply (article 6.1. c) of the RGPD).
Consent is not an appropriate basis for the lawfulness of employee geolocation. One of the conditions that must be met for consent to be valid is that it must have been freely given by the person concerned. However, given the dependence and imbalance of power that can exist in employer-employee relations, employees are very rarely in a position to refuse or revoke their consent without fear of adverse consequences. In these circumstances, consent cannot be considered to be freely given.

Geolocation systems for employee vehicles enable employers to track their employees' movements in time and space. The democratisation of these systems means that they are being used more and more frequently in the business world. However, as the use of these systems involves the processing of personal data, it raises a number of data protection issues and entails risks for employees' privacy. For example, geolocation exposes employees to the risk of being tracked in real time by their employer outside working hours, or to the risk of the geolocation system being used by the employer for purposes other than those for which it was installed.
The processing of employees' personal data that would result from the use of a geolocation system to monitor working hours does not, in principle, appear to be necessary, even though there are less privacy-invasive means that employers can use to monitor employees' working hours and attendance times. 
In fact, monitoring working hours by means of badges via a time clock system is more effective and more protective of employees' privacy.

Although the obligation to request prior authorisation from the CNPD has disappeared, data controllers are now obliged to keep a record of personal data processing operations carried out under their responsibility, in accordance with Article 30 of the GDPR. The processing of personal data arising from CCTV surveillance must therefore be included in this record.

The CNPD considers that CCTV surveillance must not be used to observe the behaviour and performance of members of the controller's staff for purposes other than those for which it was set up.
For example, an employer has the right to use images of an employee stealing goods from a CCTV system used to protect property. However, the employer does not have the right to take action against an employee when, to the employer's liking, the employee talks for too long with a customer or work colleague and this behaviour is recorded by the CCTV system. This would constitute a misuse prohibited by the GDPR.
However, the purpose of CCTV  surveillance of a shop checkout may be to protect the controller's property against acts of theft committed by its employees or by a customer/user and to ensure the safety of its staff. 
However, in order not to invade employees' privacy, the camera will have to be configured in such a way that employees behind a checkout counter are not targeted, by directing its field of view towards the checkout itself and the front of the counter, i.e. the area where customers are waiting in front of the counter, with a view to identifying the perpetrators of assaults, for example.

Cameras used to monitor access areas (entrances and exits, thresholds, steps, doors, canopies, lobbies, etc.) must have a field of view limited to the area strictly necessary to view people about to enter; those filming external accesses must not cover the entire width of any pavement running alongside the building or adjacent public roads. Similarly, outdoor cameras installed on or around a building must be configured so as not to capture the public highway or the approaches, entrances, accesses and interiors of other neighbouring buildings that may come within their field of vision. Depending on the configuration of the premises, it is sometimes impossible to install a camera that does not include in its field of view part of the public highway, approaches, entrances, accesses and interiors of other buildings. In such cases, the CNPD considers that the data controller must implement masking or blurring techniques to limit the field of view to its own property.

The right to erasure exists but is not an absolute right. Under the terms of Article 17(3) of the GDPR, it does not apply insofar as the processing is necessary:
  • The exercise of the right to freedom of expression and information,
  • In order to comply with a legal obligation which requires the processing provided for by Union law or by the law of the Member State, or to perform a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller.,
  • For reasons of public interest in the field of public health,
  • for archival, scientific or historical research or statistical purposes,
  • the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims,
You should also be aware of the rights of other people who may be affected by a request for deletion.

Any controller is obliged to inform data subjects individually of the personal data processing it implements.  
According to Article 12.1 of the GDPR, the provision of information to data subjects and communications addressed to them must be carried out in a "concise, transparent, comprehensible and easily accessible manner, in clear and simple terms".
The word "provide" is crucial here and means that the controller must take concrete steps to provide the information in question to the data subject or to actively direct the data subject to the location of said information (e.g. by means of a direct link, QR code, etc.).

There is no obligation to obtain the user's prior consent to the reading or placing of a cookie on his or her terminal equipment if the cookie is an essential cookie, i.e. :
  • Targets « exclusively to transmit a communication via an electronic communications channel » or
  • Is « strictly necessary for a supplier in order to provide an information society service specifically asked for by a subscriber or user ».
In order to garantee the most transparency possible in regards to the internetr users, the CNPD recommends to website and application operators to inform the users about the fact that they use "essential" cookies via a cookie banner for example. Furthermore, if the use of cookies involves a data processing, an information according to article 13 of the GDPR must necessarily be given to users. This information can be documented in a "privacy policy" or a "cookie policy".

If a non-essential cookie is read or deposited, i.e. a cookie that is not aimed at one of the two categories previously mentioned (see explanation of question 19), the site operator is obliged to obtain the user's prior consent before depositing or reading such a cookie.
Consent must be informed, prior, free, unambiguous and specific.

One of the requirements of the RGPD is that personal data be processed in such a way as to ensure an appropriate level of security of such data, and in particular to protect it against unauthorised or unlawful processing and against accidental loss, destruction or damage, using appropriate technical or organisational measures.
The GDPR therefore requires controllers and processors to put in place appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk to the personal data processed. They should take into account the state of the art, the costs of implementation and the nature, scope, context and purposes of the processing as well as the risks, varying in likelihood and severity, posed by the processing to the rights and freedoms of natural persons. The GDPR also requires that all appropriate technical and organisational safeguards are implemented to establish immediately whether a personal data breach has occurred, which will determine whether the notification obligation applies. Processors are responsible for putting in place organisational and technical measures to be able to inform the controller(s) of an incident involving personal data as soon as possible, so that the controller(s) can comply with the 72-hours notification period following detection of the incident.

The Computer Incident Response Centre Luxembourg (CIRCL) is a government initiative designed to collect, investigate, report and respond to computer security threats and incidents. 
The CIRCL is the equivalent of the Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT) for the private sector, municipalities and non-governmental entities in Luxembourg. The CIRCL provides a reliable and trusted point of contact for all users, companies and organisations based in Luxembourg, for dealing with attacks and incidents. Its team of experts acts like a fire brigade, with the ability to react quickly and effectively whenever threats are suspected, detected or incidents occur. CIRCL's objective is to collect, investigate, report and respond to cyber threats systematically and rapidly.
Luxembourg House of Cybersecurity is the backbone of advanced cyber resilience in Luxembourg and aims to capitalise on and further develop innovation, skills, collaboration and capacity building.
As a central player, the LHC hosts all types of activities related to cyber security. With its two centres, the CIRCL (Computer Incident Response Centre Luxembourg) and the NC3 (National Cybersecurity Competence Centre), and with key partners, the LHC supports, nurtures and serves a wide range of sectors, such as the private, public, health, education and industrial sectors.

A personal data breach is a breach of security resulting in the accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration or unauthorised disclosure of, or access to, personal data transmitted, stored or otherwise processed. Data breaches can be categorised according to the three well-known principles of information security:
  • breach of confidentiality in the event of unauthorised or accidental disclosure of or access to personal data ;
  • breach of availability in the event of accidental or unauthorised loss or destruction of personal data ;
  • breach of integrity accidental or unauthorised modification of personal data ;
Depending on the circumstances, a breach may concern confidentiality, integrity and availability at the same time, or any combination of these 3 principles.

The data controller must identify whether the data breach presents a risk to the individuals concerned. The controller can use its responses to the information requested in the notification form as a basis for determining whether the breach presents a risk to data subjects. The processor has an important role to play in enabling the controller to comply with its obligations and this includes breach notification.

Data controllers must notify personal data breaches to the CNPD within 72 hours of becoming aware of them if the breach in question is likely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of data subjects.
Where appropriate, where the personal data breach is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of an individual, the controller must communicate the personal data breach to the data subject as soon as possible.

If the data breach presents a risk to a person's rights and freedoms, the controller is required to notify the CNPD as soon as possible and, if possible, no later than 72 hours after becoming aware of it. If the CNPD is not informed of a data breach within 72 hours, the controller must justify the delay. The notification must describe the nature of the breach, provide the name and contact details of the Data Protection Officer, describe the likely consequences of the breach, and describe the measures taken or proposed to be taken to remedy the breach. The CNPD's data breach form can be used to make the notification. In addition, Article 34 of the GDPR requires that where a personal data breach is likely to give rise to a high risk to the rights and freedoms of an individual, the data controller shall inform the data subject of the breach as soon as possible. The aim of this communication is to help the data subject to protect himself or herself from the potential consequences of the data breach for which he or she may be the target. Whether the risk is high, existing or non-existent, the data controller must document any personal data breach, indicating the facts concerning the personal data breach, its effects and the measures taken to remedy it (even those not required to be notified to the CNPD). The National Commission may request access to this documentation in order to verify that the data controller or processor has complied with its obligations relating to the management of data breaches.

Risk is defined in terms of the degree of sensitivity of the data processed and the severity and likelihood of the impact on the rights and freedoms of the persons concerned (physical, material, moral impact, etc.). For example, the management of the members of an ASBL requires a lower degree of security than the management of a medical file by a doctor. The reference to the rights and freedoms of individuals primarily concerns data protection and the protection of privacy, but also extends, where appropriate, to other fundamental rights, such as freedom of speech, freedom of thought, freedom of movement, the prohibition of discrimination, the right to liberty and freedom of conscience and religion. The communication to the data subject must describe, in clear and simple terms, the nature of the personal data breach and contain at least:
  • the name and contact details of the Data Protection Officer or other contact point from whom further information can be obtained;
  • a description of the likely consequences of the personal data breach;
  • a description of the measures taken or proposed to be taken by the controller to remedy the personal data breach, including, where appropriate, measures to mitigate any negative consequences.
The means of communication used to contact the data subjects must be effective, i.e. it must be ensured that the data subjects receive the information communicated with a high probability. If necessary, public communication may be required.

Technical and organisational measures" means all appropriate measures that the controller must implement to ensure appropriate security of the personal data it processes, including protection against unauthorised or unlawful processing and against accidental loss, destruction or damage.
In the event of a data breach, the entity must implement technical and organisational measures to limit the risks arising from the data breach and to limit the impact on the data subject.
Following an incident, it is important for an entity to adapt the organisational and technical security measures to its processing operations to prevent the same type of breach from happening again".

Encryption, pseudonymisation and anonymisation are security measures.
  • Anonymisation is the processing of personal data in such a way as to make it impossible, in practice, to re-identify the data subject by any means whatsoever. The emphasis is on the result: it must be ensured that the data does not allow the data subject to be identified by "all" the means "likely" to be "reasonably" employed. An important factor is that the processing must be irreversible, so that it is no longer possible to trace a person's identity.
  • Pseudonymisation consists of replacing directly identifying data (surname, first names, etc.) in a dataset with indirectly identifying data (alias, sequential number, etc.). The natural person may still be identified indirectly, so pseudonymisation alone does not produce an anonymous data set. Unlike anonymisation, pseudonymisation is a reversible operation: it is possible to recover a person's identity if additional information is available.
  • Encryption: encryption translates data into another form, or code, so that only people with access to a secret key (called a decryption key) or password can read it. Encrypted data is commonly referred to as ciphertext, while unencrypted data is referred to as plaintext or plaintext data. The current state of the art must be taken into account, an outdated technology will not be considered valid.

Anonymisation opens up the potential for re-using data, enabling players to exploit and share their data "pool" without infringing on people's privacy. It also allows data to be retained without limitation. It should be noted that, in practice, anonymisation is a technique that destroys information. It is therefore advisable to use anonymisation when :
  • Sufficient amounts of data are available;
  • Has a clear idea of how anonymised data will be used;
  • Is able to implement an anonymisation method that will preserve the desired properties of the dataset.
To build a relevant anonymisation process, it is advisable to:
  • Examine the categories of data to be anonymised (structured or unstructured data, time series, geolocation information, etc.);
  • Delete direct identifiers as well as rare values that could make it easy to re-identify individuals (e.g. precise knowledge of the age of individuals in a dataset can in some cases make it very easy to re-identify centenarians);
  • Distinguish important information from secondary or useless information (i.e. information that can be deleted, which it is preferable not to collect at all, in accordance with the principle of data minimisation);
  • Define the ideal and acceptable level of detail for each item of information stored;
  • Define priorities (e.g. is it more important to retain a high level of detail for this information or to retain other information?).

Personal data can circulate freely from the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg within the European Economic Area (European Union, Liechtenstein, Norway and Iceland), as long as the general principles of the GDPR are respected.
Member States apply the same level of protection when processing personal data. A transfer within the European Economic Area is therefore governed in the same way as a transfer to Luxembourg and must therefore comply with the general principles of the RGPD (in particular, compliance with the principle of lawfulness, compatibility of the communication with the original processing, information of the data subjects).
A third country is a country that is not bound by the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), unlike the 27 EU Member States and the three member countries of the European Economic Area (EEA), Norway, Liechtenstein and Iceland.

Third countries may be recognised as ensuring an adequate level of protection of personal data in order to allow the transfer of personal data from EU and EEA Member States to these countries.
To date, the European Commission has recognised Andorra, Argentina, Canada (commercial organisations only), Faroe Islands, Guernsey, Israel, Isle of Man, Japan, Jersey, New Zealand, South Korea, Switzerland, United Kingdom, Uruguay and the United States (commercial organisations participating in the EU-US Data Privacy Framework only) as providing an adequate level of protection (as of 1 January 2023).
The effect of this decision is that personal data can be transferred from EU and EEA Member States to the third country concerned (within the material scope described by each decision) without additional requirements.

Various safeguards are available to data controllers or processors who wish to transfer personal data to a country outside the European Economic Area that does not have an adequate level of protection. One of the safeguards provided for by the RGPD is the use of standard contractual clauses, whereby data controllers and processors offer adequate protection by means of a contract, which is binding on those who send the data and those who receive it, and which contains sufficient guarantees to protect personal data. By way of illustration, the European Commission's "standard contractual clauses" modules can be used, or contractual clauses proposed by the company. Since the RGPD came into force on 25 May 2018, new options have become available to data controllers or processors who wish to transfer personal data to a country outside the European Economic Area that does not have an adequate level of protection. These are: - codes of conduct approved in accordance with Article 40 of the GDPR, accompanied by a binding and enforceable undertaking by the controller or processor in the third country to apply appropriate safeguards, including with respect to the rights of data subjects; and - certification mechanisms approved in accordance with Article 42 of the GDPR, accompanied by a binding and enforceable undertaking by the controller or processor in the third country to apply appropriate safeguards, including with respect to the rights of data subjects.

Controllers and processors subject to the GDPR, including those established outside the EEA, can rely on the standard contractual clauses (SCCs) adopted by the European Commission, which are a kind of model contract for the transfer of personal data.
The standard contractual clauses combine general clauses and a modular approach to take account of different transfer scenarios. In addition to the general clauses, controllers and processors should choose the module applicable to their situation, so as to adapt their obligations under the standard contractual clauses to their role and responsibilities in the data processing in question."

Binding corporate rules (BCRs) make it possible to ensure an adequate level of protection for data transferred within a corporate group both inside and outside the European Economic Area. This appropriate guarantee is particularly suited to international groups of companies carrying out a large number of international data transfers.

The controller retains overall responsibility for the protection of personal data, but the processor has an important role to play in enabling the controller to comply with its obligations; and this includes breach notification. Indeed, the GDPR specifies that processing by a processor is governed by a contract or other legal act. 
Article 28(3)(f) states that the contract or other legal act shall stipulate that the processor "shall assist the controller in ensuring compliance with the obligations laid down in Articles 32 to 36, taking into account the nature of the processing and the information available to the processor."

Where processing is to be carried out on behalf of a controller, the controller shall only use processors who provide sufficient guarantees as to the implementation of appropriate technical and organisational measures so that the processing meets the requirements of the GDPR and guarantees the protection of the rights of the data subject.
Processing by a processor shall be governed by a contract or other legal act under European or Member State law which binds the processor to the controller, defines the purpose and duration of the processing, the nature and purpose of the processing, the type of personal data and the categories of data subjects, and the obligations and rights of the controller. This contract or other legal act lays down, in particular, the obligations of the processor, which are partly taken up in clause 7 of the European Commission's standard contractual clauses.

If a processor uses the services of another processor to carry out specific processing activities, prior specific or general written authorisation from the controller is required. Regardless of the specific or general nature of this prior authorisation, the first processor must keep an up-to-date list of the other processors.

In accordance with the model standard contractual clauses for subcontracting relationships, the description of the processing operation must include the following information:
  • Categories of data subjects whose personal data is processed ...
  • Categories of personal data processed ...
  • Sensitive data processed (if applicable) and applied restrictions or safeguards that fully take into consideration the nature of the data and the risks involved, such as for instance strict purpose limitation, access restrictions (including access only for staff having followed specialised training), keeping a record of access to the data, restrictions for onward transfers or additional security measures ...
  • Nature of the processing …
  • Purpose(s) for which personal data is processed on behalf of the controller ...
  • Duration of processing …
  • For processing by (sub-) processors, also specify subject matter, nature and duration of the processing.
The information to be included on technical and organisational measures is set out in another annex entitled "Technical and organisational measures, including technical and organisational measures to ensure the security of the data".

Processors are responsible for putting in place organisational and technical measures to be able to inform the controller(s) of a personal data incident as soon as possible so that the controller(s) is/are able to comply with the notification deadline of 72 hours after detection of the incident.
A processor [...] has a duty to notify the controller of any personal data breach as soon as possible after becoming aware of it.
